In the event of an emergency involving the Baltimore Terminal butane blending system, it is the policy of the Facility to initially contact the Baltimore City Fire Department and request their assistance. The Facility maintains a trained (annually) incipient fire capability. The Facility's emergency response plans are coordinated with the Baltimore City Fire Department and Baltimore City/County Emergency Management Agency. We also maintain a relationship with the Baltimore City Fire Department. Tours and drills with members of local emergency response organizations are held routinely. These tours and drills enable the public emergency responders to become familiar with the hazards, equipment, resources and personnel in the terminal.

We are continually striving to make the Motiva - Baltimore Terminal the safest and most reliable workplace possible for our employees, our neighbors and our community.
In an effort to improve and promote system safety, Motiva looks for, and seeks employee input, on process safety improvements. The Baltimore City Fire Department is contacted regarding participation in site emergency response drills. Additionally, Motiva will work cooperatively with the community to address any concerns.

By virtue of the flammable effects associated with butane, it is necessary to observe certain safety precautions in handling butane to prevent unnecessary human exposure, to reduce the threat to employee health, and to minimize the threat and impact to nearby members of the community. Motiva Enterprises LLC
- Baltimore Terminal is strongly committed to employee, public, and environmental safety and health. Safety at the Facility depends upon the manner in which butane is handled as well as the various safety devices incorporated into the design of the process.  Furthermore, comprehensive training is provided to employees, which reinforces the safety policies and procedures of the Baltimore Terminal.
The facility has fixed inventories of butane. Butane is received by truck (transports) and stored in one (1) storage vessel. Specifically, liquefied butane is off-loaded by truck for storage under pressure (pressure reliefs set at 250 psi on the storage vessel). The butane is pumped to a blending skid for direct injection into regular and premium unleaded gasoline lines feeding the site gasoline truck-loading rack. Injection quantities are controlled via the blending skid and Bartec-Benke Analyzer. Process safety controls include excess flow valves, low-melting point (<250 degrees fahrenheit) feeds to pneumatic valves (fail closed), 85% fill shutoff on the vessel, emergency shut-off devices on the system and video display terminal, line thermal (pressure) reliefs, and grounding/interlock devices. Access to the Baltimore Terminal is restricted to authorized employees, management personnel and authorized contractors/visitors.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RELEASE POLICIES
Motiva Enterprises LLC - Baltimore Terminal is a refined petroleum product distributor. The Baltimore Terminal is an onshore, light products, bulk petroleum storage terminal used in the storage and distribution of petroleum products to retail and commercial end-users in the vicinity of Baltimore, MD. The Terminal handles and stores various grades of unleaded gasoline, low-sulfur diesel, No. 2 fuel oil, butane, ethanol, and various other petroleum based additives.
Motiva Enterprises LLC (Motiva) - Baltimore Terminal in Baltimore, MD is committed to operating and maintaining processes in a safe, reliable and environmentally sound manner. Motiva believes that excellent performance in health, safety, and the environment goes hand in hand with operating reliably, and that outstanding HES performance is of paramount importance.
The Baltimore Terminal is designed, operated and maintained in a manner that protects the environment, as well as the health and safety of our employees, contractors and the community. Motiva promotes health, safety, and the environment through programs of awareness, compliance, prevention and protection. These programs include a combination of accidental release prevention and emergency response planning.
